name: Reykjavík Art Museum
description: Reykjavík Art Museum (Listasafn Reykjavíkur) is the largest visual art institution in Iceland, operating three distinct locations across the capital city, each with its own character, collection focus, and architectural identity. A single admission ticket grants 24-hour access to all three buildings, allowing visitors to explore the full breadth of Icelandic and contemporary international art across multiple venues. Hafnarhús, located at Tryggvagata 17 by the Old Harbour, occupies a six-story former warehouse designed by Studio Grandi Architects and transformed into a striking contemporary art space. The building's industrial architecture—exposed concrete, high ceilings, and flexible gallery spaces—provides an ideal setting for cutting-edge contemporary art exhibitions. Hafnarhús permanently displays works from the Erró collection, featuring pop art and surrealist paintings by Icelandic-French artist Erró (Guðmundur Guðmundsson, born 1932), whose colorful, densely layered works incorporate imagery from comic books, advertising, and art history. The museum also presents rotating exhibitions of contemporary Icelandic and international artists working in diverse media including painting, sculpture, installation, video, and performance art. Kjarvalsstaðir, opened in 1973 in Klambratún park, is dedicated to Jóhannes Sveinsson Kjarval (1885-1972), Iceland's most beloved painter.
